pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.2: At that time a certain brahmin had invited the monks for a meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.3: When the monks had finished and refused an invitation to eat more, they went to their respective families, where some ate and some took away almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.4: Soon afterwards that brahmin said to his neighbors,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.5: “The monks have been satisfied by me.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.6: Come, and I’ll satisfy you, too.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.8: Those monks who were invited by you came to our houses. Some of them ate there and some took away almsfood.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.9: That brahmin complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.10: “How can the venerables eat in our house and afterwards eat elsewhere?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.11: Am I not able to give them as much as they need?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.12: The monks heard the complaints of that brahmin,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.13: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.14: “How can those monks finish their meal and refuse an invitation to eat more, and then eat elsewhere?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.15: “Is it true, monks, that monks did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.18: “… How can those foolish men finish their meal and refuse an invitation to eat more, and then eat elsewhere?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.19: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.20: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.21.1: ‘If a monk has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, and then eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:1.22: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.1: Soon afterwards the monks were bringing back fine almsfood for the sick monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.2: But because they were not able to eat as much as they had intended,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.3: the monks threw the leftovers away.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.4: The Buddha heard the loud sound of crows cawing,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.6: “Ānanda, why is there this loud sound of crows cawing?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.7: Ānanda told him what had happened, and the Buddha said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.8: “But Ānanda, don’t the monks eat the leftovers from those who are sick?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.10: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.11: “Monks, I allow you to eat the leftovers both from those who are sick and from those who are not sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.12: And, monks, this is how you make food leftover:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.13: ‘I’ve had enough of all of this.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.14: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:2.15.1: ‘If a monk has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, and then eats staple or non-staple food that is not left over, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.6: has eaten any of the five staple foods, even just what fits on the tip of a blade of grass.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.7: Refused an invitation to eat more:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.8: there is eating; there is staple food; it is offered by one standing within arm’s reach; there is a refusal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.10: the making it leftover is done with food that is not allowable;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.11: it is done with food that has not been received;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.12: it is done with food that is not held in hand;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.13: it is done by one who is not within arm’s reach;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.14: it is done by one who has not finished his meal;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.15: it is done by one who has finished his meal, who has refused an invitation to eat more, but who has risen from his seat;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.16: “I’ve had enough,” has not been said;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.17: it is not leftover from one who is sick—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.20: the making it leftover is done with food that is allowable;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.21: it is done with food that has been received;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.22: it is done with food that is held in hand;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.23: it is done by one who is within arm’s reach;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.24: it is done by one who has finished his meal;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.25: it is done by one who has finished his meal, who has refused an invitation to eat more, and who has not risen from his seat;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.27: it is leftover from one who is sick—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.30: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics—the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.32: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.1.33: If he receives it intending to eat it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct. For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.1: If it is not leftover, and he does not perceive it as leftover, and he eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.2: If it is not leftover, but he is unsure of it, and he eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.3: If it is not leftover, but he perceives it as such, and he eats staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.4: If he receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.5: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.6: If it is leftover, but he does not perceive it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.7: If it is leftover, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.2.8: If it is leftover, and he perceives it as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.2: if he eats it after having it made leftover;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.3: if he receives it with the intention of having it made leftover and then eats it;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.4: if he is taking food for the benefit of someone else;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.5: if he eats the leftovers from a sick person;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.6: if, when there is a reason, he makes use of post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc35:3.3.9: The fifth rule, the training rule on invitation, is finished.
